item.title: [HBASE-12387] committer guidelines should include patch signoff
item.description:
Right now our guide for committers apply patches has them use git am without a signoff flag. This works okay, but it misses adding the "signed-off-by" blurb in the commit message.

Those messages make it easier to see at a glance with e.g. git log which committer applied the patch.

this section:

The directive to use git format-patch rather than git diff, and not to use --no-prefix, is a new one. See the second example for how to apply a patch created with git diff, and educate the person who created the patch.


$ git checkout -b HBASE-XXXX

$ git am ~/Downloads/HBASE-XXXX-v2.patch

$ git checkout master

$ git pull --rebase

$ git cherry-pick <sha-from-commit>

# Resolve conflicts if necessary or ask the submitter to do it

$ git pull --rebase          # Better safe than sorry

$ git push origin master

$ git checkout branch-1

$ git pull --rebase

$ git cherry-pick <sha-from-commit>

# Resolve conflicts if necessary

$ git pull --rebase          # Better safe than sorry

$ git push origin branch-1

$ git branch -D HBASE-XXXX

Should be

The directive to use git format-patch rather than git diff, and not to use --no-prefix, is a new one. See the second example for how to apply a patch created with git diff, and educate the person who created the patch.

Note that the --signoff flag to git am will insert a line in the commit message that the patch was checked by your author string. This addition to your inclusion as the commit's committer makes your participation more prominent to users browsing git log.


$ git checkout -b HBASE-XXXX

$ git am --signoff ~/Downloads/HBASE-XXXX-v2.patch

$ git checkout master

$ git pull --rebase

$ git cherry-pick <sha-from-commit>

# Resolve conflicts if necessary or ask the submitter to do it

$ git pull --rebase          # Better safe than sorry

$ git push origin master

$ git checkout branch-1

$ git pull --rebase

$ git cherry-pick <sha-from-commit>

# Resolve conflicts if necessary

$ git pull --rebase          # Better safe than sorry

$ git push origin branch-1

$ git branch -D HBASE-XXXX

comments.comment:
+1

I thought we had text with signoff previously (I read something by Sean Busbey to this effect and is why I do signoff if patch format allows over last month or more...)
So we should always go with making author to contributor and signed off? Even now also many patch commits are like old way (adding contributor name in commit message). What do you say Stack?

If we want to do that we'll need to expand the committer guidelines to cover setting things up.

Something like

This example shows how to commit a patch that was created using git diff without --no-prefix. If the patch was created with --no-prefix, add -p0 to the git apply command. Before following these steps, you must ensure your working directory is clean. Otherwise, the autocommit step (commit -a) will coalesce your local changes with those of the contributor.

Note that unlike the case of a patch made with git format-patch, the patch itself doesn't include information on the contributor. Normally, you should be able to use the name and email address from the user's ASF Jira account to fill in the author details, below we use the example "Prathia Hall <prathia.hall@example.com>".


$ git apply ~/Downloads/HBASE-XXXX-v2.patch 

$ git commit -m "HBASE-XXXX Really Good Code" --author "Prathia Hall <prathia.hall@example.com>" \

    --signoff -a # This extra step is needed for patches created with 'git diff'

$ git checkout master

$ git pull --rebase

$ git cherry-pick <sha-from-commit>

# Resolve conflicts if necessary or ask the submitter to do it

$ git pull --rebase          # Better safe than sorry

$ git push origin master

$ git checkout branch-1

$ git pull --rebase

$ git cherry-pick <sha-from-commit>

# Resolve conflicts if necessary or ask the submitter to do it

$ git pull --rebase           # Better safe than sorry

$ git push origin branch-1

$ git branch -D HBASE-XXXX

Actually, that's not that much more work. But it sounds like enough of a change to warrant a DISCUSS thread?

So we should always go with making author to contributor and signed off?

I like Sean Busbey's prescription Anoop Sam John. He has the tooling doing the work for us. Encouraging folks to produce patches that we can just do 'git am --signoff' makes for less work for committers; any savings are appreciated when we are running multiple branches as we are doing currently. What you think Anoop Sam John?
